content:
Nice clash, harder than it looks, since you are dealing with discrete increases in the robot population that don't align with your variable n beyond the 3 day mark!

After a bit of stumbling, you realise a simple loop can solve it all for you. :)

One thing that isn't actually clarified, but is a very subtle issue, is that you implicitly assume the robots all work on a single robot at a time here. Whereas "The rate of work [being] directly proportional to the number of robots" would still be true if they worked in parallel, say "Robots work together on a single robot if the number of robots is odd, or on two robots when even, "3 robots when the number is divisible by 3", ... (with later rules superseding earlier ones). This would make the problem far more confusing, so your simplification is crucial, but it would be good to just add an explicit line saying to assume they all work on a single robot at a time.

Perhaps it would be clearer to just explicitly state:
"The time taken to complete a new robot is always 2 days / [[r]], where [[r]] is the number of robots at that point in time". Then this removes the possibility of the proportionality changing, and removes the need to think about how the robots are organising their labour.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle, it was quick, simple, and should work well for clash.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I really enjoyed this clash, it was fun to resolve. It tooks me two attempts to solve it because of a little mistake on my while loop, my bad. It's possible to solve it very quickly.

I suggest to change the constraint n <= 40 to something like n <= 25 (in accordane with your validators), because the naive implementation (like your solution) has exponential running time in n and would be far too slow for n = 40.
It seams cool!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a very nice clash! It took me a couple of iterations of error solving, and with each mistake I saw it was an interpretation error at my side, not a contribution mistake. So, nicely challenging for a change.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
This exercise is rewarding, upvoted.
It didn't work in C++

All sections
* Please format n and r as [[variables]].

Goal section
* Please format the example timeline using the ```multi-line
monospace
syntax```.

* The example seems to contradict with the cases? In the example, you say 2 robots on Day 3 and 7 robots on Day 6. However, Validator 1 expects the answer to be 3 when input is 3 and Test 3 expects the answer to be 11 when input is 6.

Thanks.

Thank you for the feedback. 
* Fixed the formatting issues. 
* The input n is the number of days the scientist will return. If the robot starts working on day 1 and n = 2, then the scientist will return on day 3. English is not my native tongue, so please let me know how I can make this clearer.
What error did you get?
Thanks for approving and I'm glad you enjoyed it!
I'm glad you like it!
Good suggestion. Updated.
I'm glad you had fun solving fun it!
Thanks for approving. I'm glad you liked it!
Thank you for your feedback. At some point, we would have to imagine a bunch of robots working on tiny parts and putting them together :) Anyway, I updated the statement to make it clearer.

Process has timed out. This may mean that your solution is not optimized enough to handle some cases.

From test 2 this till the end error appears.
My guess is that it could be an infinite loop or an optimization error. My C++ is probably too rusty to help you, but you can post your code here or on the forum so others can look at it.

I would suggest to change the Example so that the days start with Day 0 instead of Day 1 and that should reduce some confusion.

Also, please format n as a [[variable]] in Constraints section.

Thank you.
Updated. Thank you.
